DIV1.HEAD: Here begyns þe fyndyng of þe glorios confessour Antone, þe gret ermyt, of sant Jerome fro greu to latyn translated, & mad of s. Teophile, byscop at Costantynoble, in þe tyme of Costantine þe emper∣our be reuelacione of an aungelle, fro deserte of Egypt in-to þe (cyte of) Costantine, þat es to sai | þe III day Idus of Juni.

DIV2.HEAD: I.
DIV2.P: Antony, for sothe, of nobulle & religyous fader & moder I-getyn, of partyes of Egipt, wyt so grete besynes kept in cloes, þat nothyng he knew bot hys fader Ms. fad{er}, könnte auch durch fadyr aufgelöst werden. & moder & hyre menȝe. And wen he was a chylde abul to lerne letture, he gaf hym not to ragyng & want∣ones, bot wyt a burnyng desyre he gaf hym to hys doctrine. To kyrke ofte wyt hys fadyre & moder he ȝede, & chylder plays & neglegens he forsoke, to þe thyngys redde in kyrke harkynnyng, þe entent of þam kepyng in hys mynde . He wold neuer desyre oþer dayntys þan hys moder sett befor hym, os oþer nyse Ms. nyse oder nyse? chylder done; bot euere he held hym content & payde . After þe dethe of hys fader & hys moder, he of þe age of XVIII or XXti ȝere, wyt hys syster of age tendre & lytyll, he bare þe cure & þe kepyng of alle þe houshalde ful honestly. Vn(nyce we)re sex monyths endyd, þat he ne ranne to holy kyrke and dysspysed all hys ryches, takyng to mynde þe actys of þe apostyls for to folo hys sauyour: ffor, as we rede in actibȝ apostolorum, many men sold þat þai had & cast it aforn þe postyls fete, to departe it þer nede were, for to af þer Ms. þ{er}; das sonst durch er aufzulös. häkchen ist hier vielleicht, wie in m{er}ble, durch ar zu geben (wie in Schott. mss.); doch begegnet þere (dort) mit e. rewarde in heuen.

Slyke thyngys holy Antony takyng in mynd, he entyrd þe kyrke. & it happynd þe gospell Ms. gosplell, vor be fehlt to. be redde in þe wylke oure lord sayd to þe ryche man: 'If þu wylle be parfyte, go and sel alle þat þu has & gyf it to pore men, & cum & folo me!' Þe wylk gospel hard, he supposed þe gospel rehersyd for hym . Onon he went oute of þe kyrke, & þe possessyons þat he had, þat es to wytyn thre hundyrth of olywe-trees, he gaf to hys negburs, þat no hewenes suld be done to hys Ms. to hym hys. syster, & al hys meweabull thyngys he solde; and a grete quantite of golde gederyd togedyre, al he gaf to pore men, sawyng a lytyl quantyte to þe fyndyng of hys syster. Eftsons he entyrd in-to þe kyrk & hard a-noþer gosspel, were oure lord sayd: 'Thyng = think. not wat ȝe sal ete on þe morne'! þe porcyone þat he hadd reserwed, he departyd it to pore men. Þan wold he not sofure hys syster duelle at home, bot to trew & dewoute maydyns be-toke hyre, for to be gouerned & taght. And he hym-self, al erthely godys dysspysyd, a hard & a scharp iornay tok on hande. þat tyme few mynstres were in Egipt; bot, he so = who so. wold lyfen solytare lyfe, fere fro towne ferwently in godys serwyse he dwelled in holy prayers.

For-þi in a lytyll felde nere was a nolde man, fro ȝongthe l. ȝougthe? in soly∣tary lyf duellyng. Hym Antony fyrst foloed in gode contemplacyone, ffyrst be-gynnyng in place a lytyl fro þe towne; & after fere & fere sekyng wham he myght fynd ferrest dwellyng. And so, as a bese bee, wlde he neuer turne home agayn vntyll-tyme he had fone = found. a holy man to comon wyt; & þan, as he had fone a honycombe, gladly he wold turne agayne. þus he begynnys. At þe last he forgate hys fadyr ryches & al hys affynyte; all hys desyre he hauntyd abowte þat he had begone. Euere day he wroght wyt hys handes, ffor he fonde wretyne: 'Wo so workes not, not sal ete'; and all þe oure-plus of hys getyng emang pore men he departyd it. Euer he was in prayers, for he fonde wretyn: 'Sine intermissione orate'. To þe heryng of scripetures so wele he gaf hys tent þat no∣thyng suld out of hys mynd; bot alle þe comamentes of god kepyng, hys mynd was to hym as a boke . & so was he lufed of all hys brethere. To al hys felas he was obedyent, þat he gate hym thanke of alle men. If a felaw were continent, he was als contynent; & if any were iocunde, he was iocunde honestly; who so fasted, he fasted wyt hym; who so knelyd, he kneled wyt hym; he was meke & also pacyent, kepyng charyte agaynes alle men. And þus he gaf hym to al-maner of vertues, & þus hys fame began to encres, þat to none harmet in þat tyme in vertues he was found þe secunde; ffor hys neghbures & oþer monkes to whome he come, were glad of hys commyng: 'lo were commes Antony, gode felaw'. So þat þe name of hym kynd grantyd, somme as sone, & somme as brothere enterely lufed.

Antonius in þis maner gate hym lufe & desyre of euere man . þan þe enme of mankynd, in-pacyent to sofure so many vertues in a ȝong man, wyt hys holde desaytes assayled hym . Fyrst he sayd sayd = assayd. where = whether. were he myght styre hym fro hys purpose begunne, puttyng to hym mynde of wardely possessyon̄s, diffense of hys syster, nobulnes of hys kyn, luf of erthely thyngys, delytes of metes, wyne delecta∣cion & oþer flateryngys of luste luste = lusty. lyfe, atte last þe strayte ende of vertues & þe grete trawyll to comme to vertues, þe frelenes of body, þe longe space of age . When þe enme sawe þat he put hym away wyt gode thoghtys & wyt besy orysons & wyt entere thoghtys of þe passyone, þan he began to stere hym wyt vnleful thoghtys & polu∣cions . Be day he styrd hym so strongly þat ilkaman persaywed þat Antony faght wyt þe d(e)uelle; be nyghtys he stered hym so strongly wyt flesly lustes; & he wyt wakyng & fastyng walkyt(!) hys body abowte . þe deuel be nythe reformed hym-self in lyenes of a fayre woman: þan Antony putte befor hys hene þe wengeabul flammes of helle & þe bytternes of wormes bytyng & of oþer paynes. Alle þis thoghtys were confusyone to þe deuelle—see how he þat wened he hadde bene lyke vnto god, how he was scorned of a innocent! Trewly, god halpe hys serwant, þe wylke throgh his grace gaf wyctory to Antony; þat he myght scylfully say þe post∣elles word: 'Not I do þis dedys & þis wyctory, bot þe grace of god þat es wyt me enclosyd in my saule'.

At þe last, wen he myght not oure-comme hym, Antony, wyt þis temptacyons, þis most blak dragon, bot saw þat he was euer put away wyt gode cogytacyon̄s: a hedus chyld & a blake kneled downe befor Anton & wepe sore, þus sayyng: 'Many a man I af dyssay∣wyd, & now, for sothe, as I af bene serwyd of oþer holy men, so am I truly throght þi trawylle & þi prayers oure-comen'. When Anton askyd wat he was þat slyke thyngys spake, þe deuell spak & answerd: 'I am þe frend of fornycacyon, I af takyn many wep∣ynes of vnclennes & I am called þe sprete of fornycacyone Die letzten worte sind wol zu tilgen., & ȝyt I may not oure-comme þe; full many wyllyngys to lyfy l. lyfyn. in clennes I af desaywyd, fful many strongly begynnyg to oure formere fyles I af þam ham broght. I em he þat Ms. þat þat. þe prophete blames ofte∣tymes menslyden (?) So scheint die hs. zu lesen. seyng: throght þe sprete of fornycacyon ȝe be desaywyde. þe I af ofte-tymes temped, & euer am I putte abak'. When þe knyght of Cryst, Antony, harde þis, he ȝeldyd thankyngys to god, &, wyt more hardynes armed agaynes hys enme, he sayde: 'Mekyll ert þu for to be dysspysed, for þi derknes & þi age be∣tokyns vnhelefulle thyngys; of þe recke I noght, no em not aferde; Godd es my consulour, & I sall ioye opon my nenmys'. & onone at þis wordes þe deuelle wanyssed a-way . þis was of Antony a-nens þe dewelle þe fryste wyctory . Also in Antony was þe vertu of
oure sawyoure, þe wyche Ueber wyche ist wyl (st. wylche) überschr. fflessly syne condempned, þat Justifica∣cyone of þe lawe sulde be fulfylled in vs, so þat we sulde not lywen after þe flesche bot after þe sprete . Not one to Antony suf∣fysed o vyctory, no to þe deuelle o temptacione; bot þis dewelle as a lyon raumpand soghte ane entre be þe wylk he myght breke in; and Antony, wyt holy scripture enformed & taghte, knew wele þat þe deuelle ourecomen in fleschely lystes wold put no mo tempta∣cyone to hym, & þerfore more & more he ȝoked & chastyd hys body, þat he, now a wyctor, were not ourecommen in oþer synnes.

Antony þan purpossyng to constrayne hys body wyt þe ȝoke of straiter lyfe—& ȝit alle men merwelled hys grete holynes in wak∣ynge, fastynge, & prayers; ȝit was he so pacyent þat þe cruelties of hys penance wyt strenght he ourecome. Alle þe nyght ofte-tyme he lay (in) prayers; ones he ete in þe day, & þat after þe sone goyng-doune; and wyt þat refeccione thre days content, þe ferthe day he eete efte-sons . & wen he ete, he toke bred & salte & a lytyl draght of water—of flesche & wyne spek I noght, for it was not þe vse of holymen at þat tyme. In slepyng-tyme he lay in a hayre, & oþer-wylle nakyd opon þe bare grond. Oynement vitterly Ms. vitterly st. vtterly? for∣sakyng—& ȝit fulle holy mene sayd þai myght not endure bot if hyre bodys werne suppullyd wyt oynement . Antony vsede alle maner of traweles; as þe postylles command(e)d: 'When I em seke, þan em I most strong', he afferemed also þat þe strenght of þe saule enteres throght fatigacione of þe body; where-fore nothere lengthe of traywylle no meryt of tymes he re-membyrd, bot wyt luf & wyl∣ful serwage as a ȝong begynner to þe encres of godes drede he styrred hys dyssyre . He remembred ofte wordys of Helie þe pro∣phete sayyng: 'oure luf Ms. oure luf I, l. oure lord? afore wham I stode to-day'—þe wylke determened why 'hodie' was put to: for Helie countted not þe tyme þat was past bot as þan he had bene euer(e) day in striuyng; slyke he contened for to be, þat he myght plesyn to godis syght, pure in hart & redy to obey to þe wyl of god.

Antony þerfore rememberyng þat it be-howed þe seruand of god takynyng Ms. takynyng st. takyng. insampulle of grete Helie, fer fro euere towne he closed hym in a cawe; sendyng to one of hys cosyns at sertan days to bryng hym mete . & þus in a celle of merbul he closyd, only endured in holy prayeres . þan þe deuell dredyng þat throgh neghyng to hym þer suld be made ane habitacione in þe wylderenes, he gedyrd to-gedyre hys fals felachyp; he smote Antony wyt a dole∣ful wond, throgh þe wylk he hopyd to mewe hym out of hys celle— ffor he hym-self told after-ward þat þat wondyng past all þe tor∣mentes þat euer man suffurd. Bot þe ordynance of god, þat neuer fayled to men þat wele hopyng hopyng ist verb. finit., was ney . Anoþer day þis cosyn, of wham we spak of before, come & broght hym mete . þe wylk brak
þe dores & saw hym ly nakyd on þe grounde as dede . He toke hym vppe on hys schulder & bare hym vnto þe towne . þe wylk thyng harde, a grete multitude of hys neȝburs & of Ms. of of. hys kyn comme abute, full of sorow wen þai se þe corse emong þam . And euen abute mydnyght come a grete gladnes to all men þat syttyn abute: for þe saule of Antony resorted agayne to þe body, &, seyng (alle) alle fehlt im ms., rasyd vp hys heued . & onone al men fel on slepe, sawe onely he þat brogh hym þeder; & hym he called to hym, prayyng to bere hym agan to hys celle . And when he was borne agan to hys celle, for grewosnes of hys wondes he mygh not stonde; he felle downe, prayng, & after hys prayers wyt clere woyse he sayd: 'Lo here I em, Antony, ȝe deuelles; I drede not ȝoure wondes, alle-of Ms. of = if, wie öfter. ȝe bryng more grewus tormentes; noman may depart me fro þe luf of Criste' . & þan he song þis vers: Si consistant aduersum me pre∣lia, non timebit cor meum—þat es to say: 'of Ms. of = if, wie öfter. ȝe take agayne me batylles, my hart sall not dreden'. When he had sayd þus, þe deuelle, enmy of alle godenes, merweled þat after so grewus wondes & betyngys he durst more reprewe hym; he gedyre = gedyrd, ist praet. to-gedyre hys howndys &, wexyng wode, sayd: 'Noþere wyt þe sprete of fornyca∣cyone no wyt wondyng I may not oure-comme hym; take all ȝoure wapynes! more & reghtlekere he salle bene a-sayled; lat hym fele, lat hym fele! he salle knaw wyt wham he strywes & angyres'. One þe deuels assented & were redy to (þe) enmy Ms. my enmy. to plesse hym . Sod∣anly abowte Antonys celle was made a grete noys, þai rywyn downe hys house & þe walles made opyn, & many score d(e)uelles pered to hym, summe in lyknes of bestes, summe in lyknes of ser∣penttes; þai fulfylled onone þe place wyt fantesys of lyons, of bulles, of wlues, of neddyres, of serpentes, of scorpeons, of pardes & of bers, & all þis bestes aftyre þer kynde made deuellyk noyse: þe lyone rampand cryyng, þe bolle rored & bolyed, þe serpentes hyss∣yng, þe wlwes rowngyng, þe pardes of dyuers colowres schewyn Ms. schewym. dyuerse desaytes & coloures . Wyt þis noys Antony gretly turmentyd & adrad bodyli, bot wyt-in in saule he was vngastfulle; & þan way∣mentyng—þe wondes of flesche expresseden (i)t Ms. expressedent st. expresseden it., in hys wytte neuer∣þeles he induryng, he spak as scornyng hys enmys in þis maner: 'If ȝe hadden any thyng of streght, it suffyst one to comme to ba∣tell; bot for ȝe bene so febulle, wyt grete multitude ȝe tempe me . & þis es a grete febulnes of ȝow & ane infirmyte, þat in ȝoure awne lyknes ȝe dare not comme, bot clothe ȝow in forme & in þe schape of oþer vnresonabulle bestes'.

And eftsons he trested in god, sayde: 'Wat may ȝe done? If my lorde af gyn ȝow pouere in me, se, I am redy, dewoure me! & if ȝe may not, besie ȝe ȝow not so ydylly; þe seyn of þe cros & my faythe to god bene a wall in-expungnabull agayn ȝour temptacions'.
Many thretyngys þai thret hym, & gnast þer tethe on hym, for þai myght not spede of þer temptacions, & for þe grete scornes þat he gaf þam. Jhesus of hys serwant not forgetfull in hys nedys, was hys defendure: for anone as he lyftyd vp hys henen to þe heght of hys house, he saw þe derknes of deuelles wanysse away & a sone-beme on hym dessende; & aftyre þis beme dessendyd & appered of þe sone, þe deuels wanysched away, and all þe sekenes & sore of hys wondys sodanly was heled; hys edyfycacione and hys celle, þat sodanly was throwen done, sodanly was reedyfyed. Anon Antony vndyrstode þat Jhesus was nere, & wyt grete syghynges of hys hart to þe lyght þat Ms. þat þat. apered to hym, þus he spak: 'Where was þu, gode Jhesu, ware was þu? why was þu not here at þe be∣gynnyng for to hele my wondys?' And a woyse ansuerde: 'Antony, Antony, here I was, bot I abode forto se þi baytell; now, forsothe, þu has manly foughten & neuer fledest, I sall euer be of þi con∣saylle, & I salle make þi name knawen be alle þe warlde'! When þis was harde, Antony rose, & was so streghtyd in god & in gode prayeres as he had neuer bene hurtyd . And þis tyme was Antony of þe age of thyrty wynter . Fro þens wyt wyll redy he vndyr∣fongyng þe ordyre of relygyone, he ȝede to þis halde harmyt a∣bowne & sayde & prayd hym þat þai myght dwelle to-gedyre . Wen þis holde harmet was dede, he all-one ȝede in to a crewyse of a hylle for to duelle, ware no-man sulde af persawyd hym no cummen to hym . Ȝyt þe deuelle wold not sesse; ffor-why he wyllyng to lette hys purpos, he cast a syluer dysche in hys way . Onone as An∣tony saw it, he knew it was þe deuelles dyssayte, & sayd: 'How cam þis siluer dysche in þis desert? If any man hade lost it, he wolde af soght þer-aftyre . þu deuelle, þis es þi crafte; ȝyt sall þu not lette my wylle, þi syluur be to þe in-to euer-lastyng perdy∣cione'. As sone as he had sayd þis, (þis) þis fehlt im ms. dysche of syluur as smoke fro þe fyre wanysched . Anon after, not in fantasse, he sayd, he saw a grete weg of masse golde—and wedyre þat þe deuell fyned it to Anton or elles þat heuenlyche vertu schewed it, þat es vnknawne; neuer-þe-les we knaw þat it was gold in sothenes.

Antony merwellyng þe magnytude of þis schynyng golde, wyt a grete heyng, os os = as. wo suld fle burnyng, he went to þe hylle were þe flode paste . He fonde a deserte castylle, full of chasabull bestes. In þe wylke þis new gest toke hys habytacyone; and at hys com∣myng a grete multytude of serpentes flowyn away. Onone he closyd þe entre. Loues for sex monythes, as custom es, to Thebeis he bare wyt hym: for ofte-tyme alle a ȝere þai woll lastyn hole; & of water he hade a lytylle; & þus solytory he dwellyd, wyt no-man, throw þe ȝere . Men broght hym brede, & ȝyt no worde wold he sppek to þam . To to ist zu tilgen. many men þat come be dysyre to sene hym & to seken hym, be nyghtys-tyme abydyng at hys celle-dore, ware þai hard voys sayyng to Antony: 'Warto ioynestu þe to þis habyta∣cyone?
wat thyng fyndes þu in deserte? warto comme þu fro ferne cuntres? þu myght not suffure oure asayllyngys'. And fyrste þai wyt-outyn, heryng þis voyse, supposyd þat men wyt leddyrs hade entered in to hym and hyd þam þare; after-warde þai lokyng in be kynes, saw no-man . þan þai wyst wele þat deuelles strywed so wyt hym; & wyt gret drede agaste, þai askyd help of Antony . And he neghyng to þe dore to comforte hys brethere, þat þai suld not drede þam & also þat þai suld passyn away he prayed þam, & bad þam, if þai ware agast, to blysse þam, '& wyt þat sene ȝe salle styre þam' . Wen þai were past away, he duelled stylle all-one, no-þing wery no ne Ms. none. agast of þe deuelles temptacyone . Eftsones companyes of men comme to þis wyldernes, trowyng to fynd hym dede. An∣tony sang þis verse: Exurgat deus e. c., þat is to say 'God ryse he vppe, & hys enmys be þai disparpyled & fle þai fro hys face, alle hys enemys fle þai away as smoke, & as wax flees þe fyre, so fle þai fro þe syght of god'; & efte-sones he sayd: 'Alle folk af gane abowte me, & in þe name of god I am wenged of þam'.—Wen he had endyd in solytary lyf XX ȝere, depardyd be alle þe tyme fro þe seght of man, many men cowetyng hys purpos to folo, & many knawne men come to spek wyt hym, & so strongly presed to hym: at þe last þai byrst vppe hys dores. And onone hewenlyk þai ware made new. Hier fehlt ein satz. Alle men dred þe grace of hys mouþ & þe clere∣nes of hys body & þe wytnes Am rande steht brygh, als ob in brygh(t)nes corr. of hys face: for it was noþer bolned wyt rest, no wyt fastyng made lene, no wyt temptacyone of þe deuelle made pale, bot euen þe contrary; as of of = if. he neuer hadde trawaylde, þe furmere fayrenes of hys membris endured, to þe low∣yng of oure lord Jhesu Cryst, to wome (es) honour & worchipe euer∣lastyngly. amen.

DIV2.HEAD: II.

Here begynnys þe fyndyng of þe gloryus confessour Antony & grete hermete, of saynt Jerome fro greu to latyne translated, & made of saynt Teophyle, byschop Ms. of at. at Constantynenoble, in þe tyme of Costantynoble (!) Emperur, be reuelacion of an aungelle, fro desert of Egipt in-to þe cyte of Constantynoble, þe thyrd day of Julij.(!) l. þe thyrd Idus of Juni, vgl.
DIV2.P:
(I)N þe tyme of l. when st. of. Costantyn þe Emperur gouerned þe Empyre in-to Biȝance cite, it be-felle þat he hade no chylde þat myght aft∣yre hym gowerne þe emppyre: & was to hym grete sore . Be days & be nyghtys to kyrke he come in fastyng & in prayng orysons, & be∣sekyng & askyng of god to luf hym & lenne hym a sone . And þus he went in þe kyrke þat was helowed in þe worchyp of þe holyest name of oure lord Jhesu Cryst Sophire, and in þe same kyrke he made ornamentes opon þe autyre of þis holy name, & oþer orna∣mentes be alle þe kyrk in-numerabul . So god, hawyng compassyone of hys mekenes, grawntyd hym a dogter . þe bechsop Teophile cal∣lyd-to after two ȝere he made hyre to be crystyned in þe same
kyrke, and þe same byschop called hyre Sophie after þe same name Sophire. Ms. sophire Sophire, doppelt.

Þis same maydyn at þe age of ten ȝere was so wele lerned, þat all men spake of hyre prudence; for scho was ryght fayre of face & of feture . By-fell a day þat scho went forthe wyt oþer madyns in-to an orchard, for to ete appulles & for to drynk wyt þe same madyns of a welle . Reght as scho dranke, IX (nene) deuels in entyrde Ms. in entyrde, in ist wol zu tilgen. in-to hyre body, and onon scho ȝelled, as a beste or a lyone . þe toþer maydyns onon tok flyght & cryed wyt grete woyce: 'Grete Emperur, socur þi dogter!' þe emperur þis heryng, wyt all þat warne in hys palas, he comme into þe orcherd, & hely began to say: 'O þu schaper of heuen & erthe, byere-agayne of mankynd, so∣cure & helpe my dogter!' and began to go to hyre-ward, sayyng 'dogter Sophie' . And scho began to gnast wyt hyre thethe & gaf grete ȝellyng, & þan þe deuelles sesyd & were stylle.

Anone þe emperur tok Ms. to mit überschr. k. hyre be þe hand and ledde hyre in-to hys palas . & þan þe spretes mewed hyre, and scho gnew hyre tong & gnastyd wyt hyre tethe, þat noman myght halde hyre; & brak yryn chenes, & cryed as lyons, pardes & tygrys done: so þat alle men were adrade . þan þe emperur fulfyllyd wyt mekyl soro, lete make a cage of yren, & bonde þe madyn fast & put hyre þer-inne. So was scho þer-in fowrtene nyghtys, for dred of etyng of men & bestes, þat noman durst negh hyre . Bot god, þat wold not his madyn be parysched bot sawed, made þe deuels wyt-in hyre body to cry wyt grete woyce be þe mowthe of þe maydyn: 'Antony, þe harmet of Egypte, sall woyde vs hens, for he brynes vs eueryday' & þus þai cryd al a ȝere . Where-fore þe emperur wyt most sorow fulfyld, for he wyst neuer wedyre to send hys messyngers nor in wat party of Egypt þe body of hym to fynde; þe emperur enduryng long in þis thogh, sent for Teophile, byschop of Costantyno(b)le, & for alle þe wyse men of hys empyre, & enquered of þam dylygently were þai knew any scriptur of holy fadyrs & þe lyfe of saynt Antony Nach Antony ist þe harmet of Egypt auspunctiert., & in wat place hys body were beryed; 'ffor þis deuelles þat dwell in my dogter body, cry euer wyt-outyn sessyng: Antony, þe haremet of Egypte, he sall put vs hense' . þe byschop wyt all hys clarge & wysemen seyng þe sorow of þe Emperur, made bryng a-for þam all þe bokes þe wylk in greeo of þe lyfe of holy fadyrs & heremetes þai myght fynd . And redyng in þam, fonde of saynt Antony confessor & haremyte: how fro chyldyd he hade heloyd hys body to oure lord Jhesu Cryst, & comande hys brethyre, wen he dyed, þat þai suld bery hym so prewely þat noman wyste, sawe only god & þai, & þat body neuer ware fon(n)e Ms. foneie. . When þis thyng & oþer thyngys þai had fone wretyn of saynt Antony, of þe certante
of h(is) Ms. h st. his. beryyng cowthe þai no-thyng fyndyn. þan þe same byschope in þe mornyng, comandyng pes, sayd: 'For it plesyd, my chylder, to saynt Antony þat no-man suld knawe þe place of hys beryyng bot onely god, þer-for, breþer, I comande ȝow to meke ȝow in askys & hayre, fastyng ilk-ane of ȝow IX days in alle orysons & drede of god, & wyt a woyse pray we to god þat he wowchesayf to vs, hys serwantys, to schew þat precyus tresure, & by hym þat he woche∣sayf to delyuer hys madyne Sophie, þe dogter of þis worthe Emperur, fro þis deuelles þat trawylyn hyre'. Endyd þe fastyng of IX days wyt all mekenes & dred of gode; for Cryst wolde no lengger so pre∣cyus a tresure bene hyd, bot þat all men in þe warled it suld be schewed & þe name of hym knawne vnto þe day of dome: reght a∣bowte mydnyght þer apered ane awngel to þe emperur & to þe byschop Teophile, sayyng to þam: 'Constantyne' . & he answerd: 'I here þe; wo ar þu?' 'I am Gabryel þe archanle, messynger of all∣myghty god; and for þu astandyd(!) Ms. a standyd. euer-more in þe precept of god, þi prayere es hard & now it as perchyd as = has, ms. perrechyd. heuen, & I am commen to telle þe how þu sall fynd þe body of saynt Antony & bryng it to Byȝance, to þe hele of þi dogter' . Anon þe emperur ros oute of hys bed & wolde af toched & felte þe angell; bot þat þe awngel wold not sofure . In þe commyng of þis holy aungelle Gabryelle, os þe same Emperur tolde, all þe palys was als lyght as þe sonne . And þan sayd þe angelle to þe emperur: 'It es not leful to þe to toche me, bot I am commen for þe hele of þi dogter . And þer-for, to-morne aryly calle þe byschop Theophile & send hym to-warde þe partes of Egypt wyt XII clarkes relygyous & dredyng god. & I wyl be wyt hym algates, & þai sul not dredyn þe tempest of þe see' . & þe same way he told byschop Theophile, & þan he wanysched a-way. As sone as þe emperur rose, he sent for þe byschop Theophile & told hym & þe clarkes of hys cyte how þe aungell had tolde hym be vysyon; þe same told þe bischop Theophile . On þe morne þis byschop wyt XII clarkes relygyous entyrd a chyppe syngyng & sayng 'lorde, be oure lyght & oure hele, whom we drede', & so saylyd þai forth to-warde Jerusalem . þai had a ioyfull wynde, and nothyng was to þam contraryus . Aftyre þe seuen days þe wynd cessyd, & þan þai began to row, to þer strenght fayled þam . þan þe byschop began to comforte hys breþer, sayng: 'Breþere, dred ȝow not! god es oure helpere, schypman & gouernour; & se, a wylfulle wynd sal apere to vs'. Aftyre oþer VIII days þai come to Jerusalem, & worchepyd þe holy resurrectyon & þe cros; after þai ȝode to Bedlem, and worchepyd þe holy crasche. & þan þai blyssyd þam & entyrd in-to þe cyte of Alysaundyre, & after, wyt marchandes of þe same cyte, þai entyrd Libie, þe way of XXti days, to þe flode of Nyli, in a strete þat es called Ephesos, in þe partes of Egipt . & þare þai spered of þam were saynt Antony wyt hys brethyre in þe serwyse of god were wont to dwelle . And
þai answerd: 'In a hyi-wode he dwelled long tyme, weydyre ȝe af ȝit XXti days iornay & fywe, & be all þat way sul ȝe fynd non abytacyon bot dyuers bestes infinit'. þai onon crossyng þam wyt þe sene of þe holy cros, þe day foloyng þai tok þer iornay, sayng: 'Lord, ryse vp & disparpil þi enemys, & all þa þat haten þe fle þai fro þi face!' After thre days ende þai comme to scharpe & hey mountaynes, & so þai ȝede þe way of XX days, euer emong lyons, lyberdes, tygres, beres & vnicornes, & euer throght þe holy name of saynt Antony þai went vn-hurte . At þe last þai come be an harmy∣tache & beholdyn it fast, þe wylke saynt Antony fyrst made; & þan cowthe þai no ferre . Agayne þam come a holde man of full grete age, clere of face & fare of chere . & wen þai had kyst to-geder, he tok þe byschop be þe hand & went wyt hym to þe ȝate of þat her∣mytage . þane þe byschop Theophile sayd to þis olde man: 'Wo sette fyrst þis place & ordande it, & wo es lord here?' And he gaf hym none answere, bot wyt hys hande made a sene of pes—þan vnder-stode þe byschop þat it was þe rewell of þe house, & char∣chyd hys brethere to kepe þer mowthes fro spekyng; and onone þis olde man wanyshed away: þe wyche was saynt Antony, as þe byschop knew after be rewelacyone . Wen þis amonyssyngys were done, anon come out of þat harmytage twenty freres, wyt wolne copys, wyt crosses & encense—ffor god be rewelacyone hadde schewed þe comyng of þam; syngyng wyt ioy & sayng: 'Go a pylgrimage, ȝe chosyn men toward threwthe, & we sall syng & ioy to god, oure saweoure'. And þis endyde, þe pryor of þat wyldernes kest þe byschop Theophile & hys brothere be ordyre . Made & endyd pes betwene þam, þai led þam Ms. ledyn, mit überschr. a, statt led þam. in-to þe kyrk of þe harmytage, & in þe cloyster þai begunne to wasshe þe fete of Teophile & hys brethere, & song: Maudatum nouum, þat es to say: 'A new mawndment I gyf to ȝow: þat ȝe lufe to-gyder' . Wen þis was done, wyt gret sylens þe prior ledde hym in-to þe fratur, were þai suld ete, &, þe belle rong & handys waschyn, he made þam to sytte. Efte-sones þe belle rong þe secunde tyme: þer rose on vp of þe brethre of þe hous & sette brede on þe borde, of merwelus whytnes, & herbes & rotes of wunder Ms. undeutlich. sawour . þe hermytes sytte wyt þer gestes meynged . þe belle rong þe thyrd tyme: water was gyn þam to drynk . And wen þai had dronkyng = dronkyn, part praet. thryse, þe prior rong þe belle: and þan al þe brethyre wyt grete meknes & sylens & hewenes rysyng fro þe borde, & went in-to þe kyrk; þe holy fadyrs go before, & after þam þe prior & þe byschop, syngyng & sayng: Myserere mei deus, vnto þe ende, be ordyre . Wen þai were entyrd in-to þe kyrke, and endyd al þer ofyce þat es called post commestionem, þan þe pryour sayd to þe byschop: 'þe water þat ȝe drank at þe mete, es of a welle ordand to vs of god, hawyng al gode sauour. þer es anoþer welle besyd vs hawyng thykke water, & þat god ordan for
oure fader Antony, & of þat bene wassyn þe fete of oure brethyre and of oure gestes, for euer a day it es hote(?) . þere Ms. þere st. þe? loues þat ȝe saw afor vs, it es wnknawne to vs were þai bene bakyn, bot þis we knaw þat euere day þer comme to oure celare two lyons, þe wylk were wyt saynt Antony to dygge þe pytte were þe body of saynt Paule, þe fyrst hermyte, was beryd, & bryngys vs als many loues as suffyce to vs & al oure gestes . An þus oure fader Antony ordaned & dysposed, wen he fyrst sett þis place, and ordand vs here fowre & twenti brethyre . One pasche-days & on sonondays & on oþer solempne days oure loues ere dobulled & broght be þe same lyons. On þis maner as ȝe af hard, fro þe tyme of oure holy fader Antony vntill þis tyme myrabulle god as fed vs . Wen we comme to þe kyrk to syng oure messes, þe lampes in oure kyrk, þe wylk saynt Antony made in þe worchep of oure lady, bene lyght, & fro þe morne to þis tyme þai be not lessed'. þis done, þe prior wyt gret sylence sayd to þe byschope Teophile: 'lat vs say ewensang'! & wen þai hadd sayd, he gan to beholde þe kyrk þat saynt Antony had made, how wonderfully it was made . It was made of stones, & no tymbure, & sqware, & þe cloyster bysyde þe walle of þe kyrk. & þe kyrk was of mesure twyse so long as brode, & it had two wyndows afor þe auter þat was in-myddes, & two befor þe auteres þat were syde Ms. syde = a-syde., and þe auteres Ms. ati{er}t{er}es. were of crystalle, and foure & twenti stalles be-for þe auter; bot þe prior sete was heher þan þe toþer, wyt dyuerse precyus stons & margarites onourned Ms. onoureed., & wyt wonderfulle warke sett; it was sett betwene two queres, wyt grete ornamenttes made fayre . Nowþer Ms. nowyre. in kyrk noþer in al þe harmet∣age no sownd no woyce was hard, nor noman so hardy to spek wyt-outyn þe prior leue; bot wen any thyng was nedful to any brothere, he went to þe prior, knelyng and bowyng hys hede wyt all reuerans, wrytyng in a payre of tabulles wyt a poyntell thyngys þat were necessary to hym. He, os a gode fader, þe ensampull of hys holy fadyre Antony holdyng, to euere man deliuered þat was nedefull to þam . þan þe byscop Teophile sayde to þe prior: 'How may in manky(n)d be so contynuale sylence as I af sene emang ȝour breþer?'. þan þe prior sayd: 'Fader, I knawlege afor my saue∣our: fowrty ȝere it es, sene oure holy fader Antony past away fro vs and put vs here, were nomans woyce we heryn bot oure awne wen we say oure serwys' . þan sayd þe beschop Teophile: 'Es it lefull for vs to be here wyt ȝow, & þe wyll of god?'. & þe prior sayd: 'Whi as as = askes. þu me, fader? I af consaywed þat god has schewed to þe wat þe behowes to done or þu comme here; & wen þu as done, it behowes þe & þi breþer to turne home agayn'. Os þai stode þus in spekyng, þai saw a byrde wyte as snaw, bry(n)gyng Ms. brygyng. in hys mowthe lyght fyre, commen in at a wyndow, & lyghtyd alle þe lampes befor euery auter in þe kyrk, & þan past away & left
þam burnyng . Teophile, þis seyng, askyd þe prior wat it mente . þe prior ansswerd: 'Wyte ȝe wele þat euere pasche-day & euere fest of oure lady & in þe fest of oure holy fader Antony & in þe fest of þe apostylles he doys þus; þise & oþer thyngys he doys'. þe byschop Teophile began to telle þe cause of hys iornay, & how he was sente fro þe emperur of Costantynobull for hys dogter þat was trawyll Part. praet., = trawylld. wyt IX deuelles, for hyre delyberacione: 'for þe spretes af cryed þat þai wyld neuer ouwte Ms. ou wte. of hyre body, to þai se þe body of saynt Antony at Costantynobul. And here-fore be we com∣men & now as Ms. we as, we scheint auspuncliert. rowed þe partes of þe see & of þe land; & ȝit fynd we noman þat can tell vs in certayn were þe body of hym is. Bot ȝe, serwantes of god, rew on vs, for þe pyte of god, if ȝe any thyng know of þe tombe of þis precius confessour, þat ȝe teche vs; þat be ȝow we may fynde þis precius tresour & ȝeld thank∣ynges to almyghty god'. þan þe prior ansuerd: 'Fadyres & breþer & serwantes of þe hey god, vs oure lord has put in þis place be praere of saynt Antony, to kepe lyfe vntyll þe day of dome . And he paste away fro oure predycessours wyt two of hour breþer, hys dyscypulles: þat es to wytyn wyt Hyllary & one þat was called Priour, and wyt þam he orda(n) Ms. orda. by Egypt twelfe minsters; & in turnyng-agayn he dwelled in þe partis of Syphie Ms. syphie st. Libye? in an orybulle and grete wyldernes be-syde Egypt, were saynt Antony ordand ane oratory & many celles, & þer he dwelled wyt hys breþer . Bot wen hys olde membrys were dysturbulled & comme to hys laste days, we reden þat he commawnde to hys two breþer þat noman bot þai suld knaw þe place of hys tombe . Bot long-agone þat place es dystrued wyt thewys, & we knaw nothyng ferrere, bot god of hys grete mercy mak to ȝow rewelacyone . Lat vs abyde to-gedyre thre days & thre nygh in orysons, & pray we to god þat he woche∣sawe to vs, hys serwantes, to schew vs þe way to þat place were es put þis precius body' . And so it was done . þis fastyng endyd wyt all orysons & mekenes: wyls Ms. wyle oder wyls? þai wer at messe, þe aungell Gabryel comme wyt all bryghtnes & suetnes, holdyng a bille in hys hande, & lete it fal on oure lady autyre, wyls Ms. wylk. þai stod þer before þe prior; and þai alle þat stod abowte, for drede of þe aungell þai fel doun growelyngys to þe grownd, lyk dede men . And þan þe prior of þe mynster sayd to Teophile, þe byschop: 'Take þis letter &, wat es wretyn þere, do it be order! for ȝoure prayere es hard'. And þus þe aungel, seyng þam alle, styeng to heuen . And þan sayd þe prior: 'My breþer & my fadyres, þis wysyone þat ȝe af sene, was Gabriel, messynger of þe hye god, þat apperd to vs and has gyn vs þis letter, þat ȝe blys ȝow wyt þe sene of þe holy crose & þat ȝe gone ȝoure way ordanede: for god sall be wyt ȝow & ful∣fyll ȝour desyre . & þer salle appere to ȝow a bryght starne & go befor ȝow, & stande stylle obowne þe place were es beryd þe body
of saynt Antony. And þer wyt prayers dygkyng = digging., & ȝe salle fynde þe body of hym, famed wyt-owtyn ende, sal be enhawnsed & euer renewed(!) be alle þe warlde . For slyk a grace god has grawntyd hym, þat, wo-so-euer askys any þing of hym reghtfully, he sal hafe hys bone; anoþer grace god as grauntyd hym: to sawe all bestes fro all maner sekenes' . Wen þis letter was red & messe done of þe prior, þe byschop Teophile wyt hys breþer, blyssyd of þe prior, toke þer lewe, makyng in þer forehed þe sene of þe cros, & passyd forthe . þan appered to þam a fulfayre bryght starne, as þe sone, and went before þam; & a woysse þai hard þat sayd: 'Sew þe sterne!' And þus þai foloed þe sterne, euer besekyng þe helpe of al-myghty god, wyt teres & cryyng . So went þai forthe, be scharpe ways and hie hylles, to þai comme to a plane place, full of herbes & appulles of wonderly sawour; and of þam þai toke and hete = ete., & ȝeldyd thankyng to god . After-ward þai tok þer iornay be-twyxe hie hylles & gastfulle, were entyrd no sone, nor tre growyng nor greys; bot serpentes & dragons in-numerabul, lyons, tygres, pardes, muys(!), as wlues, coccatryces, aspes & vnycornes, & oþer wylde bestes þai fonde & se, þe names & þe kynde of wam þa knew not; bot, þe powere of god helpyng, þai past away vnhurte . þe sterne fro þam neuer sessyd . After xix st. six. days paste, þer come in þer nose a stynk∣yng sawour, so intollarabull þat þai fell to þe grond lyk dede men; and þan þai prayd þat god suld take þer saules . Wen þai rysyn, þai se a grete lake, & a grete multitude of serpentes fyred, & þe sawles of men wyt all þe bodys wyt grete dragons swaloed. Of þat lake comme oute gret lamentacyon & soroyng not a lytyll; and a woyce obowne sayng: 'þes es þe place of payns Ms. of payns of. at þe day of dome, in þe wylk sal be turmentyd all men þat af for-swo(r)ne Ms. swone. Cryst & not kepyd hys commamentes' . þai heryng þis woyce, þai were agast; bot þai passed vnhurt . Wen þai had paste after-warde þe iornay af fowrte days, þai comme to a merwillus place & to a lyt∣ylle feld, bot full gloryus, þat was ful of all maner of appulles & frote & all swet sawoure. Opon þe wylk place þe starne þat ȝe(de be)for Ms. ȝe for st. ȝede befor. þam, stod vnmewebull, and a woyce come to þam & sayd: 'Dygge here! & ȝe salle fynd a precius tresore'. þai knew not in wat parte of þe feld þai suld dygg, and so Ms. so oder se. a wyte byrde as snaw, wyt a rede bylle, apared & sate opon a tre, þe wylk was in maner of a toute Ms. toute.; & þere welled oute a plentyuous welle of alle maner of god sauour, and als swete as pyment . & þis byrde sowne began to schoder hys we(n)gys Ms. wegys., as sacryn belles as wo say, & schewed þat þai suld dygeg = dig. þere . þan þe byschop Teophile wyt hys clarkes fell downe in prayers . At þe laste þai harde oure þam mery songes & felt swete sawour; and wen þe byschop lyftyd vp hys hewed & lokyd in-to heuen, he saw saynt Antony emong aungelles standyng
& prayng for all synfulle men. And þan þe byschop thankyd god sayng: 'God makere & schewere schewere of alle hyd thyng, þu knawes þe cause of my iornay; I beseke þi mekenes & þi maieste þat to (me) me fehlt im ms., most vn-worthe synfulman, for þi grete mercy wochesawe to schew me þi priwyte, & send me sum socour, be þe help of wham we may dygge & fynd þis tresore I aske'. Wen þai comme wele depe, þai were not bolde to scrape fere, dredyn = dredyng. for to touche þe holy tresoure . þan þe byschop wyt hys clarkes enteryng in, he fonde a stone & a grawe, in þe wylk was wretyn wyt grew letteres & ebrew: þat þer þe body of saynt Antony, wyt Hyllary & Pryour, hys dyscypulles, was beryd . þai redyng þis scripture, were ful∣fyllyd wyt mekylle ioy. & obowne þam þai harde a woyce of aungel∣lys syngyng & prayseng god . & as þai raywyd vp þe stone, slyk a sawour comme emong þam, þat þam thoght þai ware in paradyse . And þan þi toke þe bere & put it opon þe ded bodys, & Teophile sayd: 'In þe name of Jhesu Cryst & of saynt Antony, ryse vpe!' And so þai went alle nyght, and euere hard oure þam full swete songes and woyces of aungelles, & it semed to þam as þai warne in para∣dyse; legyouns of aungelles euere song befor þe body. saynt Antony, bot delyuer vs sone fro þis howse!'. þe byschop & þe Emperur & all oþer stode in prayers, abydyng þe myrackylle of god . & as þai endured in þer orysons, þe deuelles wyt lamentacion & grete noyse, wyt thowndyrs & erthe-quakes, out went fehlt, vielleicht absichtlich. of þat dylycate body, & left hyre half qwyck & half dede opone þe grownde . þe byschop tok hyre vp be þe hand & raysyd hyre vp fro þe erthe . And scho cryed: 'I wylle neuer fro-hens-forward be departyd fro þis precyus tresour, for now I saw in my sweuyng l. swenyng? my lord saynt Antony, þe hermete, affyng þis deuelles in hys handes & þam grewsly betyng & tormen(t)yng'. þus was þe Emperures dogter Sophie merwelus delyuered fro þis wyckyd spretis, helpyn helpyn = helpyng. þe holy body of saynt Antony . þan þe Emperur gart make a precyus tumbe, of Iwery & gold & precyus stons wndyrly made: in-to þe wylke þis holy body wyt grete solempnyte þai putte in; and locked it vnder XII lokkes, & put obowne a titule wretyn wyt letteris of greu & ebru: 'Here þe body of Antony confessor & hermete lyes & restes, fro dyshert Ms. dysherd oder dyshert? = desert. of Egypt translatyd of Teophyle þe byschop' . þe two lyons þat come wytht hym fro Egypt, & þe two wolues, wyls þer lyfes endured, duelled wyt hym, kepyng hys tumbe . Whoso∣euer come and askyd any thyng, prayng reghtfully, of (þis) holy confessor, he had hys prayere & was delyuered of al maner of in∣fyrmyte . Of þat sepulcre come oute so swete a sawour, as all þe spycery in þe warlde had bene putte þer-in. A-noþer grace god sent hym: þat, if any beste had any infyrmyte, saynt Antony called, onone he was del(i)uered . Who-so-euer wyt clene hart & grete deuo∣cyone þis holy confessour Antony & hermete wyt onest prayers prayde, in what-maner necessyte þat it be, wyt wylle he schall af hys prayere, to þe plesyng & lowyng of oure lord Jhesu Cryst, to whome es worchep & ioy in-to þe warlde of warldes, amen.

DIV2.HEAD: III Here begynnys þe translacyone of þe gloryus confessor and hermet saynt Antony of Vienensis.
DIV2.P:
For god faueryng of saynt Anto(n)y þe lyf, of blyssed (saynt) Der text ist hier verderbt. Ms. mynd st. saynt. Attanasie, of þe kyrke of Alysawnder Erchebyschop, to þe lernyng of trew men in clere wordes we Ms. we we. af a legend; dere breþer, ȝit is es nedeful þat we af wrytyn how þe body of hym fra þe cuntres of Thebayde was broght to oure cuntres, & of what persons so precyus a tresour fro so fere cuntre myght be broght . To summe it semys in-possybulle þat a body, in so fer a cuntre beryed & in so perlyus a place, & only not knawen bot to two persons & to all oþer men vnknawne, & after-warde takyn vp & to þis cuntre of Vienense wyt many & vnhard merueles broght . Bot þis sal not be trowed in-possybulle, for oure lord Jhesu, as in þe texst of þe lyf of þis blyssyd man es rede, þe coflute of deuelles ourecommen, wysybullyk apperyng to hym &, how swete he was, schewyng, emong oþer thyngys he be-hyght hym þat he suld make hys name
to be knawne be al þe warld. Growyng by euere day hys my∣rakylles, fleyng wexed is fame emang pepul . & þis be þi gyftes, lord Cryst. As þi-self sayd in þe gospelle, þu sofurd not þat þi lan∣terne burnyng Ms. burryng. & brygh, þi same serwante Antony, be hydde in a dyrke place, bot þat he be put on a candellstyk—þat es for to say in þe heeste place, to gyf lyght to alle men þat bene in þi meke hows . So, lord, fro day to day þu makys hym merwelus, þat seke men fro most fere cuntres & regyons ful many þu sendes to hym. þe wylk so sone here = ere, are. delyuered fro burnyng of þe fyre of helle, how sone þai do reuerens to þe holy relykys and aske hys helpe wyt dewoute mynde, woweng to be hys seruant;—onone on þe mornyng þai ben alle hole, or in quyete pese fro þis laborus lyf þai passyn vnto god . Not a few oþer wyt diuers infyrmytis trawylled, it es seyn þat he has helyd, & dede men restored to lyfe . Agane∣warde summe þat as calange possencyons of his seruantes, or has made any wow to hym & wyt-drawne it, wyt þe same fyre of helle þai or bestes af bene smytyn: for throght hys holy merytes þis weniance of god come to alle þat done iniure to hym or to hys serwantes . How of of = oft. tyme þis has be-fallyn, it es not in faculte to telle . þise thyng lefte, þat we af purposed late vs telle, trewthe kepe Der text ist hier verderbt.; þat we af hard, on oure litel manere we sal schew.—þare was an Erylle Gwillem, þat was a grete conquerour,—þe qwylke now for þe desyryng of hys gode lyfe þe wylke he had layd in mynstres saynt Gwillem es called—had a sone, Jacelyn be name, a worthy man . þe wylke Ms. þe wylke þe wylke., wen he comme to mans state, went to Jerusalem because of pylgrimage. þe wylke pylgrimage endyd, to þe cow(r)t Ms. cowt{er} statt cowrt. of þe emperur of Costantynople turnyng, anense þe emperur & all hys men grete grace he fond . Wen he had abydyn þer be many days, & was dere to all men, at þe last he desyred to repayre to hys awne con∣tre, & come before þe emperur forto take hys lewe. Bot þe emperur, þat was glade of þe presens of hym, dyfferd to gyf hym lewe, & þat he suld dwelle forthe wyt hym, frendely he besoght hym; of hys tre∣sore what-so-euer hym lykyd, he commanded hym to take . Bot he desyryng noþer golde nor syluur no none othere ryches; bot þe bere þat Ms. þat þat. þe body of saynt Antony lay onne, he dyssyred, & hade. And ȝit þe emperur had leuere af gyn hym anoþer gyft, for als mekyll as he hade grete trest in saynt Antony & mekyll worchep praet. hym & lufed hym & made many prayers to hym;—bot neuer-þe-lesse he wold not deney it hym, for als mekyll as all oþer gyftes he re∣fused . þat bere he gladly resaywyd for a gret gyft; takyng hys lewe of all men, heyng wyt all hys company he began to turne hamward; trestyng so mekyll in þe relyke þat he had, þat he sup∣posed non aduersary suld dyshese = dissese, vgl. disherd = desert. hym—& certanly reght, as
god says: 'all thyng bene possybul to hym þat be lewele'. Ms. lewele st. lele oder lewe wele. Nothyng hewy felle to hym, þowthe he passed emong hethen men; bot sekyrly & smartly þai comme home to þer hawne . So it befelle þat he, & all hys kyn after hym, be many ȝeres, whyder þai ȝede, bare it wyt þam & wyld neuere lewe it by-hynd þam—in so mekyll þai trayste þer-inne þat þai supposed of none hewele Ms. hewale oder hewele?, wylles þai had it wyt þam; bot all thyng felle to þam in prosp(er)yte Ms. prospyte., als lang as þai had it in þer presens . And þerefore, as I sayd, where þat euere þai went, þai made it to be borne befor þame; wyt-owtyn þat þai wyld not go—þe wylk, it es no dowte, þai dyd it of grete dewo∣cyone . Bot ȝit, wen it comme to þe popes knawlage, he demed it a fole-hardynes & vnconabull, þat slyk persones suld af so holy relykys of so holy a confessor vndyre þer kepyng and bere þam emong armed men in batayle . þer-fore to one of þe kyn þat was called Gwido, þat be reght of herytage calanged þe relyke & be en∣sawmpull of hys faderys place Ms. phace; die stelle ist verderbt. bare hamme wyt (hym) Ms. ham me wyt, hym fehlt., þe same pope sent þat he suld nomore vsyn þat maner Nach maner ist bot þat ausgestr.; auch mare ist zu tilgen. mare, but sumwhare in sum abbay of monkes dredyng god he suld take þam it for to kepe . þe wylk maundment takyn, þe nobull man wyld not(!) obeyen l. disobeyen?; bot, consyll gedyrd of hys fre(n)dys, to þe monkys of Mownt Maiour, þat were of gode couersacyone & of gode name, he tok þam it to kepe . þe wylk, as þai had a grownde where þai sulde set a mynstere, þai made it to be keped; and slyk sped þai had throw þis relyke þat in schort tyme it comme to an ende.—þis Gy gaf þam a grownde to make þe mynster on, & many oþer landes, wyt sewen kyrkes, & tythes to þam partenyng, euerlastyng to endure, so þat habytours of þe mynstere myght af mete & drynk & clothe . And a - noþer place not fer thens he gaf þam, in þe wylk a house of almos suld be set, in þe wylke hous pore men & all þat ware dyssesed wyt þe fyre of helle & (come) for to beseke þe helpe of saynt Antony, suld bene resaywed & kepte. Forþer∣more, þat none of þam þat suld be hys successours myght calange any thyng of þis forsayde gyftes, he made þam fre fro alle hys. How dewoute he was anense saynt Antony & all hys serwantes euer wyls he lyfed in þis warlde, os I trow, no tong may tell; & not vn∣worthely he was full trew and wyt-outyn gyle a man of Israel, þe wylke was well tendyre of age and spronge of ful nobull kynde, al-maner ryches & worcheppes of þis warlde fleyng he dyspysed & to pore men all þat he myght hawe he departed in þis warld trans∣satory & passyng, þat þe godes of god allmyghty he myght send in-to þe lande þat es euer-lastyng.—þis Antony was þe fyrste þat vsed hermetes lyf after Paule þe fyrst hermet, whom Antony beryed, & þe rewle of all þe hous of monkes of Egypt he ordened . þe wylke Ms. wyt þe wylke.
Antony wyt Dieses wyt ist überschrieben. þe deuel fele tymes faghte & neuer was oure-commen, bot as smoke drowe hym away in-to þe hayre = air., lewyng be-hynde hym þe fylthe of hys presence . What more: so grete grace þes holyman had for to helen men traweled wyt deuelles & wyt oþer diuerse seknes & infyrmytes; þat vnnyce any man come to hym & prayd to god & saynt Antony of helpe, þat schapyd away vnheled . Blyssed es þat place þat as slyke a man of so grete vertues & of so many praysyng! Worchep we hym, most lofed frendys, as oure meke patron, foloyng, be oure lytell maner, hys ensaumpulles of hys lyfe: þat, hys meryttes helpyng, we may be sawed in þis present lyfe fro þe burnyng of þe fyre of helle & in þe lyfe to commen, and at þe laste þat we mon commen to þe same lyfe þat he es in, & hawe euerlastyng blyssednes. Grawnttyng oure lorde Jhesu Cryste, þat wyt þe fadyre & þe holy gost lywen(!) & regneþ god in-to warld of warldes. ame(n).
DIV2.TRAILER: Explicit partem vite Antonie Vienensis . pro posse meo feci opus istud.
